Governance Plan Rejected by Undergrads
The governance plan was rejected
Yesterday 587-454. Undergraduates
turned down the plan, which
featured an Arts and Sciences
Representative Council, but faculty
and graduate students supported it.
All three segments had to support
• the plan for it to be accepted.
The future of the Temporary
Advisory Council was placed in
doubt by the rejection, with two
undergraduate members, Rick
Posen and Allan Fein, quitting.
There is also the possibility of

graduate and faculty members
resigning. Dean Benton would not
comment on the TAC's future.
Approximately 30% of the undergraduate body voted, with 465
voting against the plan and 189
supporting it. Only 20% of graduate
and post-doctoral students voted,
backing the plan 169-91. More than
40% of the faculty voted, with 96 for
and 31 against.
The governance plan, which
proposed departmental guidelines
and a committee on instruction, was
formulated this summer by a

committee chaired by Graduate
Dean Robert Strider.
Those involved with the governance plan, including Deans Strider
and Benton, were not sure what
course would be followed after the
rejection.
The Student Council had opposed
the plan because of a lack of
delegated authority to the ASRC,
and weighted voting in the amenment procedure. SC member Chris
Ohly said they would survey
opinions on governance and come up
with alternative plans.

Dean Strider: The View From 236 Gilman
By TED ROHRLICH
You walk in and Robert Strider's office is like
most others on the second floor of Gilman Hall. It
looks out on the quiet quadrangle. It is scrupulously
clean.
And the colors—orange-brown combinations-are meant to leave the holder with just that right
feeling of pressing drive and preoccupation.
But there's no pretentiousness, even when you
look for it. The memorabilia smiles from its place
on the mantle, and it doesn't blind you with that
'low and behold an academic' grin. It's the
eXecutive toy, a fishing picture with that big one,
and the over-sized bright yellow flower from a loyal

- Robert Strider

secretary--the 'what to get for the man who has
everything' series, personalized over the years.
Strider is sitting on a corner of the desk, one
wingtipped foot dragging off in the direction of the
fireplace. The wood is in a closet behind the desk.
He has done time with textiles, construction, the
Marines and "just bumming around the country."
'Working at various jobs of that type, playin'
poker.. all of these contribute to how good you are
when you become a dean."
The laughter never interrupts the words. It gently
nudges them aside and then barrels forth for an
unfailing six syllables of its own. He tries to get a
.reaction, searching for company, hand outstretched, reaching off the desk.
A Lucky Strike emerges and he lights it up. It's
two o'clock and the first pack of the day is almost
gone. The dean-designate for Undergraduate and
Graduate Programs is back from his usual Faculty
Club siesta.
Strider is worrisome these days. There's a tinge
of pathos. And he would much rather talk about
governance than himself.
He put a lot of time in last summer chairing the
committee, playing the great compromiser for nine
weeks, five days a week, and now all that time is
coming to a vote. He'd put it off or move it behind
him if he could.
"Thinking about the governance issue did not
begin last spring with the Strike Committee," he
says. "Now they certainly affected the timing,
getting it started on an emergency basis over the
summer...and in some senses I feel a little bitter
about this, that they managed to get accomplished
what I hadn't been able to get accomplished."
His voice is clear and strong, but forced out over
a rumbling undercurrent of unmeshed gears, and
tempered by a boyhood in Carthage, North
Carolina.
The last of the high-ranking administrators to
have servect, under three University presidents,
Strider has been around a long time. He's seen a lot

of growth and he sees it from the point of view of
beneficent evolution.
"One of the advantages or disadvantages about
time in a place is to have a little difference of
perspective...And I don't mean to imply anything
about the good old days. But, you see, a lot of you
don't understand that prior to two or three years
ago, there were no committees that advised
anybody on anything."
"Back in the fifties we were groping with the role
of the faculty. Now, we're groping with the role of
the students, and this is a question that has interested me and intrigued me and teased me for
some time..."
"You look at me as an administrator. I taught one
to three courses here for 17 years consecutively.
But then, I got involved all along with other
things...I even did penance one time as assistant
plant manager."
Strider never got his Ph.D. His field is economics
and the book shelves brim with texts on accounting
and finance. He came to Hopkins in 1950 as an instructor in the School of Business--"the lowest of
the low on the totem poll."
He set up the first office of financial aid, rose to
.become Asst. Dean of the Faculty of Philosophy
and finally, Dean of Administration.
One thing. He knows how to relax, and it's not
book and pipe in hand. It's shooting a game of pool
in the Faculty Club, starring in the Hounds of
Homewood Poker Club, fishing on the Bay. And
don't ever call him at kickoff time Sunday afternoon.
He relaxes with Dean Shaffer, George Benton,
Bill McElroy--the ones who've been around a long
time.
"I've had a very interesting and, in a sense, a
very unique experience here, in that I've worked in
lots of places...
"And I've enjoyed it." He'll tell you that, and you
don't quite know whether to believe him.

Reinstate Promotions
Dean Benton's decision to limit faculty promotions
because of the division's current financial squeeze is
foolhardy. Promotions for faculty members, as well as
any other University employee, should be based on
merit, not economics.
Benton's plan is not only discriminatory to junior
professors who were not here during Hopkins' golden
years, it also creates constant job instability, one of the
fastest ways to lose competent personnel.
An idea commonly expressed by the faculty is that
professors be encouraged to take voluntary salary cuts.
An even better idea, which has not been widely circulated, is that the faculty and administration should
aggressively seek new sources of support-government
or otherwise.
The University needs additional money, not massive
cutbacks, to tide over its rapid expansion in the past two
decades. The administration should be careful not to
retrench Hopkins into extinction.

Beefheart Licks Decals, Squid Eats Dough
By P. NAMOR
"A squid eating dough in a
polyethylene bag is fast n' bulbous,
got me?"
Don Van Vliet alias Captain
Beefheart is a musical genius. Not
genius in the decayed common sense
of the word (everyone from Einstein
to Brooks Robinson is a genius.) But
an original creative talent producing
significant innovations in rock
music.
In the past the Captain was known
as Frank Zappa's either mentor or
protege, or as some freak who
livened up under- and dangerouslyclose-to-aboveground rock mags
with quotes like "There are only
forty people in the world and five of
them are hamburgers." This should
change. Now Captain Beefheart, and
his Magic Band, have released their
fourth album, titled "Lick My
Decals Off, Baby."
Beefheart has progressed over
much territory since his musical life
began. "Safe As Milk," the first
album, was done in 1964. Truly incredible that sophisticated rock
songs like "Electricity" and "Zig
Zag Wanderer" could have been
done in an era when people were
digging on "Can't Buy Me Love"
and the latest Dave Clark Five.
"Safe As Milk" was good rock, delta
blues, great rock, and the erratic
flights of Beefheart's voice.
To praise Beefheart as the
greatest white blues singer is to
underrate his astonishing vocal
prowess. Possessing an enormous
range, he sings with such naked
overwhelming energy that it seems
his voice must shatter under the
tension. Never.
Unmistakeably, the Captain
exerts subtle control over every
warped note, every unexpected
inflection. He's an oracle of a
hundred voices, one for each effect
and two or more for each song.
Sometimes it's a visceral blues
bellow, in other pieces a recitation
close to monotone (appreciation
requires repeated listening.)
Made in 1968, "Strictly Personal"
was the next album. It was the
damburst, the seminal creation.
Beefheart's following two records
represent the refinement and
maturation of the ideas behind
"Strictly Personal." Although
altered somewhat without his approval before release, the album
forcefully proves the emergence of a
new revolutionary talent whose
impact should rival that of the first
rock genius, Chuck Berry.
There are no horns here - the
Captain sticks to vocals and
mouthharp - and the Magic Band
have straight names. On two continuous sides "Strictly Personal"
blends everything from blues
through rock and jazz on into
electronic music.
Beefheart's innovation: to destroy
the attachment of rock to a tune (a
traditional linear song structure.)
Only when the bass and drums
repeat a foundation rhythm is there
the sense of some definition of
formal unity.(On a couple of tracks,
and occasionally on the later
albums, the Magic Band puts
together some straight hard rock
that would make the Stones envious.)
Most of the time, however, the

Captain Beefheart and an
bass and drums are left free to
wander and experiment on almost
the same level as the lead instruments. Beefheart songs usually
open with a jarring discordant
rhythm which is either developed or
abandoned for something wholly
new, all lunging toward an often
incongruous conclusion.
Beefheart has advanced beyond
extended improvised jazz breaks
(popularized by Cream) which
make concessions to tune at the start
and finish. This is not to say that
melody has been denied, for it
hasn't. The crudely primitive blues
pieces on "Strictly Personal" are
outstanding. But Beefheart's
melodies exist as original
fragments, varying from merely
interesting to innovative novelty.
Since "Strictly Personal" reliance
on studio effects and distortions
diminished considerably as the
Captain expanded his own repetoire
of instruments and turned to the
band itself to create the weird unnatural sounds.

cut.) With a new Magic Band under
his direction Beefheart shifts plainly
toward the disciplined freedom of
jazz.

Decals Off, Baby". Clearly a third
record to the "Trout Mask" set, the
latest album is a minor disappointment. Perhaps my expectations were too high. With the
exception of one filler instrumental
all the songs are excellent, shouting
out again the churning searching
creativity and finely-regulated
chaos of "Trout Mask." Beefheart's
singing and musicianship excel his
previous standards of genius, but the
progress is one of degree and not
kind.

features Beefheart on bass clarinet,
tenor and soprano saxes, and vocals.

Horn Rollo on electric and slide
guitars, Rockette Morton on Bass,
Drumbo on drums and former
Mother Art Tripp on drums and
marimba (an instrument never used
before, now adding a touch of
variety.)
For those who received an insufficient taste of the "flowing"
turmoil of Beefheart's harp figures
on "Strictly Personal," and
lamented its absence from "Trout
Mask," the Captain plays a
chromatic on "I Love You, You Big
Dummy." Grating unrestrained
tones pour out from the instrument,
sometimes suggesting the soundtrack to "Forbidden Planet,"
sometimes resembling a harp.
Admittedly it's not the expressiveness and finesse of a Sonny
Terry or Little Walter, but then that
was (almost) another music.
Other notable points of the new
album: "Japan in a Dishpan" is an
instrumental, harsh blurts of tenor
progressing from incoherence to

insanity, wavering riffs terminating
in forced screeches unabashedly
reminiscent of Coltrane (Beefheart
also cites Ornette Coleman as a
,major influence.) The song ends
with a surprise: a few juvenile solo
sax whimpers, a very funny self mocking comment on what has just
gone before.
"Flash Gordon's Ape," the
record's longest piece, is a mournful
and very intriguing collage of bass
clarinet and tenor and soprano sax.
But, unfortunately, th Captain limits
his playing on the album as a whole.
More horns and harp would have
been a definite improvement.
A word on the lyrics (all words and
music on all albums by D. Van
Vliet ). Except for a few unusual
anti-war remarks on "Trout Mask,"
the poetry is not tethered to
meaning. Fragments of concrete
images (favorites: animals and
insects) are juxtaposed with no
continuity, no apparent origin or
direction. One thing stands out: a
satirical punning humor, a quality
also evident in the music. Beefheart
employs words chiefly for their
sounds and endless sound combinations.
The lyrics become the. music,
adding color and dimension to the
music ( in a fusion perhaps possible
only due to Beefheart's incredible
vocal diversity.) Some titles from
the new album: "I Wanna Find a
Woman That'll Hold My Big Toe Till
I Have To Go," "The Smithsonian
Institute Blues (or the Big Dig),"
"The Clouds are Full of Wine (not
Whiskey or Rye)."
After four consecutive successes
in record making - something unprecedented in rock - the next
venture for Beefheart should be a
concert tour. He was scheduled for
the Atlanta festival this summer but
missed it..A live show would be truly
unbelievable, proving to all that the
Captain is an authentic genius.

Reinstate Promotions
Dean Benton's decision to limit faculty promotions
because of the division's current financial squeeze is
foolhardy. Promotions for faculty members, as well as
any other University employee, should be based on
merit, not economics.
Benton's plan is not only discriminatory to junior
professors who were not here during Hopkins' golden
years, it also creates constant job instability, one of the
fastest ways to lose competent personnel.
An idea commonly expressed by the faculty is that
professors be encouraged to take voluntary salary cuts.
An even better idea, which has not been widely circulated, is that the faculty and administration should
aggressively seek new sources of support-government
or otherwise.
The University needs additional money, not massive
cutbacks, to tide over its rapid expansion in the past two
decades. The administration should be careful not to
retrench Hopkins into extinction.

Beefheart Licks Decals, Squid Eats Dough
By P. NAMOR
"A squid eating dough in a
polyethylene bag is fast n' bulbous,
got me?"
Don Van Vliet alias Captain
Beefheart is a musical genius. Not
genius in the decayed common sense
of the word (everyone from Einstein
to Brooks Robinson is a genius.) But
an original creative talent producing
significant innovations in rock
music.
In the past the Captain was known
as Frank Zappa's either mentor or
protege, or as some freak who
livened up under- and dangerouslyclose-to-aboveground rock mags
with quotes like "There are only
forty people in the world and five of
them are hamburgers." This should
change. Now Captain Beefheart, and
his Magic Band, have released their
fourth album, titled "Lick My
Decals Off, Baby."
Beefheart has progressed over
much territory since his musical life
began. "Safe As Milk," the first
album, was done in 1964. Truly incredible that sophisticated rock
songs like "Electricity" and "Zig
Zag Wanderer" could have been
done in an era when people were
digging on "Can't Buy Me Love"
and the latest Dave Clark Five.
"Safe As Milk" was good rock, delta
blues, great rock, and the erratic
flights of Beefheart's voice.
To praise Beefheart as the
greatest white blues singer is to
underrate his astonishing vocal
prowess. Possessing an enormous
range, he sings with such naked
overwhelming energy that it seems
his voice must shatter under the
tension. Never.
Unmistakeably, the Captain
exerts subtle control over every
warped note, every unexpected
inflection. He's an oracle of a
hundred voices, one for each effect
and two or more for each song.
Sometimes it's a visceral blues
bellow, in other pieces a recitation
close to monotone (appreciation
requires repeated listening.)
Made in 1968, "Strictly Personal"
was the next album. It was the
damburst, the seminal creation.
Beefheart's following two records
represent the refinement and
maturation of the ideas behind
"Strictly Personal." Although
altered somewhat without his approval before release, the album
forcefully proves the emergence of a
new revolutionary talent whose
impact should rival that of the first
rock genius, Chuck Berry.
There are no horns here - the
Captain sticks to vocals and
mouthharp - and the Magic Band
have straight names. On two continuous sides "Strictly Personal"
blends everything from blues
through rock and jazz on into
electronic music.
Beefheart's innovation: to destroy
the attachment of rock to a tune (a
traditional linear song structure.)
Only when the bass and drums
repeat a foundation rhythm is there
the sense of some definition of
formal unity.(On a couple of tracks,
and occasionally on the later
albums, the Magic Band puts
together some straight hard rock
that would make the Stones envious.)
Most of the time, however, the

Captain Beefheart and an
bass and drums are left free to
wander and experiment on almost
the same level as the lead instruments. Beefheart songs usually
open with a jarring discordant
rhythm which is either developed or
abandoned for something wholly
new, all lunging toward an often
incongruous conclusion.
Beefheart has advanced beyond
extended improvised jazz breaks
(popularized by Cream) which
make concessions to tune at the start
and finish. This is not to say that
melody has been denied, for it
hasn't. The crudely primitive blues
pieces on "Strictly Personal" are
outstanding. But Beefheart's
melodies exist as original
fragments, varying from merely
interesting to innovative novelty.
Since "Strictly Personal" reliance
on studio effects and distortions
diminished considerably as the
Captain expanded his own repetoire
of instruments and turned to the
band itself to create the weird unnatural sounds.

toward the disciplined freedom of

kind.

before, now adding a touch of
variety.)
For those who received an insufficient taste of the "flowing"
turmoil of Beefheart's harp figures
on "Strictly Personal," and
lamented its absence from "Trout
Mask," the Captain plays a
chromatic on "I Love You, You Big
Dummy." Grating unrestrained
tones pour out from the instrument,
sometimes suggesting the soundtrack to "Forbidden Planet,"
sometimes resembling a harp.
Admittedly it's not the expressiveness and finesse of a Sonny
Terry or Little Walter, but then that
was (almost) another music.
Other notable points of the new
album: "Japan in a Dishpan" is an
instrumental, harsh blurts of tenor
progressing from incoherence to

insanity, wavering riffs terminating
in forced screeches unabashedly
reminiscent of Coltrane (Beefheart
also cites Ornette Coleman as a
,major influence.) The song ends
with a surprise: a few juvenile solo
sax whimpers, a very funny self mocking comment on what has just
gone before.
"Flash Gordon's Ape," the
record's longest piece, is a mournful
and very intriguing collage of bass
clarinet and tenor and soprano sax.
But, unfortunately, th Captain limits
his playing on the album as a whole.
More horns and harp would have
been a definite improvement.
A word on the lyrics (all words and
music on all albums by D. Van
Vliet ). Except for a few unusual
anti-war remarks on "Trout Mask,"
the poetry is not tethered to
meaning. Fragments of concrete
images (favorites: animals and
insects) are juxtaposed with no
continuity, no apparent origin or
direction. One thing stands out: a
satirical punning humor, a quality
also evident in the music. Beefheart
employs words chiefly for their
sounds and endless sound combinations.
The lyrics become the. music,
adding color and dimension to the
music ( in a fusion perhaps possible
only due to Beefheart's incredible
vocal diversity.) Some titles from
the new album: "I Wanna Find a
Woman That'll Hold My Big Toe Till
I Have To Go," "The Smithsonian
Institute Blues (or the Big Dig),"
"The Clouds are Full of Wine (not
Whiskey or Rye)."
After four consecutive successes
in record making - something unprecedented in rock - the next
venture for Beefheart should be a
concert tour. He was scheduled for
the Atlanta festival this summer but
missed it..A live show would be truly
unbelievable, proving to all that the
Captain is an authentic genius.
